section.title: Overview
section.para: The event_flatstore module provides a logging facility for different events, triggered through the &osips; Event Interface, directly from the &osips; script. The module logs the events along with their parameters in plain text files.

section.title: Flatstore socket syntax
section.para:
Meanings:
flatstore: - informs the Event Interface that the events sent to this subscriber should be handled by the event_flatstore module.
path_to_file - path to the file where the logged events will be appended to. The file will be created if it does not exist. It must be a valid path and not a directory.

section.title: Exported Parameters
max_open_sockets (integer)
section.para: Defines the maximum number of simultaneously opened files by the module. If the maximum limit is reached, an error message will be thrown, and further subscriptions will only be possible after at least one of the current subscriptions will expire.

section.title: delimiter (string)
section.para: Sets the separator between the parameters of the event in the logging file.

section.title: escape_delimiter (string)
section.para: Optional replacement sequence that will be written instead of the delimiter whenever this character (or sequence) occurs inside a string parameter. This allows you to keep the log file parse-friendly even when user data itself may contain delimiter symbols.
If set, its length must be exactly equal to the length of delimiter.

section.title: file_permissions (string)
section.para: Sets the permissions for the newly created logs. It expects a string representation of a octal value.

section.title: suppress_event_name (int)
section.para: Suppresses the name of the event in the log file.

para.emphasis: Default value is 0/OFF (the event's name is printed).

section.section:
rotate_period (int)
When used, it triggers a file auto-rotate. The period is matched against the absolute time of the machine, can be useful to trigger auto-rotate every minute, or every hour.
Default value is 0/OFF (the file is never auto-rotated)
Set rotate_period parameter
... modparam("event_flatstore", "rotate_period", 60) # rotate every minute modparam("event_flatstore", "rotate_period", 3660) # rotate every hour ...
`

section.title: rotate_count (int|string)
section.para: Defines after how many written lines the log file is rotated. The value may exceed the 32-bit integer limit; in that case pass it as a string, e.g. "5000000000".

section.title: rotate_size (int|string)
section.para: Sets the maximum size of a file before it is rotated. A size suffix of k, m or g (multiples of 1024) may be provided. Very large values can be supplied as strings, e.g. "8589934592" for 8 GiB.

section.title: suffix (string)
section.para: Modifies the file that &osips; writes events into by appending a suffix to the the file specified in the flatstore socket.

The suffix can contain string formats (i.e. variables mixed with strings). The path of the resulted file is evaluated when the first event is raised/written in the file after a reload happend, or when the rotate_period, if specified, triggers a rotate.
This parameter does not affect the matching of the event socket - the matching will be done exclusively using the flatstore socket registered.

para.emphasis: Default value is "" (no suffix is added)

section.title: Exported Functions
section.para: No exported functions to be used in the configuration file.

It makes the processes reopen the file specified as a parameter to the command in order to be compatible with a logrotate command. If the function is not called after the mv command is executed, the module will continue to write in the renamed file.
Name: evi_flat_rotate
Parameters: path_to_file
MI FIFO Command Format:

The event is raised every time event_flatstore opens a new log file (manual evi_flat_rotate, auto-rotate by rotate_period, or thresholds rotate_count/rotate_size). External apps can subscribe to monitor log-rotation activity.
Parameters:

listitem.para: timestamp – Unix epoch (seconds) when the rotation was performed.
reason – one of the strings count, size, period or mi.
filename – full path of the new log file.
old_filename – full path of the previous log file, or empty string if none existed.
